text: in July 2005 William coos owned a driver
for a plumbing company in Brooklyn was
injured at work when a boiler
delivering fell on him mr. Kazan filed a
claim for compensation but what started
with a fall became a tumble through the
pitfalls of New York's workers
compensation system
last April mr. Kazan was examined by dr.
Hirschl Samuels a so-called independent
medical examiner with the state's
workers compensation system under New
York state law mr. Kazan was allowed to
videotape his examination this is
footage from that examination which was
also taped by dr. Sandoz assistant the
newer times compared the tape of the
examination with the medical report that
followed that report prepared by a
company called all borough medical was
signed by dr. Samuels as a truthful
account of his medical opinion but as
this tape shows the report contradicts
the doctors own key findings about mr.
Chris Owens condition dr. Samuels began
to see examination by asking mr. Kazan
whether his back is sore to the touch
however on page two of the report that
dr. Samuels signed the text reads quote
there is no tenderness to palpation over
inferior angle or over the spinous
process from t1 through t12
dr. Samuels then asks mr. Koo sone to
bend first to one side then to the next
but the report increases mr. Corso into
flexibility to what it calls normal
range 25 degrees on the left up from 15
degrees in the examination and 25
degrees to the right up from just ten
degrees in the examination dr. Samuels
goes on to check the reflexes in mr.
Hassan's legs
so for someone
but on page three the report claims
reflexes on both legs to be two plus
more than the one plus the dr. Samuels
dictates for the right leg during the
examination next dr. Samuels asked mr.
Kosan to bring his chin to his chest
however on page two of the report mr.
Cohen's forward flexion has been
increased from 30 degrees to 40 bringing
it closer to what the report calls
normal range the New York Times asked
dr. Samuels how he accounts for the
discrepancies between the videotape of
the examination and the written report
that you signed I have no idea how these
errors to get because I have no I have
no part whatsoever in transporting what
I see into the into the report I have no
idea somebody do a lot of goofs
I'm sure you know a lot of groups that
have a big effect of a surprise benefit
that's the major things you call out
numbers
nothing gets written down the person
leaves then you sit down or she sits
down to write in a number from memory
how do you be sure you're remembering
the right numbers after they've left no
not easy
are you sure you're putting down the
right numbers I'm sure of anything after
after this conversation why not write
them down while you're calling them out
no well I don't know of course you're
saying it's a year apart but I'm going
I'm responsible and I feel very uneasy
because
behind behind behind this thing many
things may be written but if if I had to
actually read each one of those reports
I could never do it
did you think we got all barreled
changed your numbers I wouldn't put a
sign and I wouldn't I would not deny it
if that could happen all bro medical the
company that prepared the report at mr.
croissant examination would not discuss
his case or the comments made by dr.
Samuels last August a judge approved an
agreement between mr. casona and the
insurer under which mr. cusan received
one hundred and fifty five dollars a
week in workers compensation benefits
mr. Kosan says he is unable to live off
that amount
